docs.abstract: Article on opposition to and support for latest efforts in Nassau and Suffolk counties to protect bar and restaurant workers from prolonged exposure to secondhand smoke; government and industry officials estimate that as many as 50,000 Long Islanders work in smoke-filled environments; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN RYERSON, the owner of McGuire's Restaurant and Comedy Club in Bohemia, said he went $250,000 into hock two years ago to create a separate room for smokers. There was no other choice, Mr. Ryerson said last week, if he were to comply with a 1995 Suffolk County law that sought to protect non-smoking patrons from secondhand smoke. ''It was that or go smoke-free and find another job,'' said Mr. Ryerson, adding that, for his business, smoking is the difference between profit and loss.

headline.main: California Jury Allots Damages Of $28 Billion To Ill Smoker

docs.abstract: Jury in Los Angeles awards staggering $28 billion in punitive damages to Betty Bullock, smoker with lung cancer who accuses Philip Morris Inc of luring her into lifelong tobacco habit with fraudulent advertising and marketing; award is largest punitive damage amount ever granted individual plaintiff in smoking case; Bullock's lawyer, Michael Piuze, says jury saw company documents that he says proved Philip Morris engaged in 50-year conspiracy to hide harmful health effects of its products; says he expects company to appeal and that Bullock, who is in final stages of cancer, will not see any of damage award; says he is gratified to have defeated Philip Morris which, along with other cigarette makers, is suffering string of court losses (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles Superior Court jury awarded a staggering $28 billion in punitive damages to a smoker with lung cancer who accused Philip Morris Inc. of luring her into a lifelong tobacco habit with fraudulent advertising and marketing. The award, to Betty Bullock, 64, of Newport Beach, Calif., was by far the largest punitive damage amount ever granted an individual plaintiff in a smoking case.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Antismoking Advertisements

docs.abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg takes his campaign for smoke-free workplace legislation to airwaves, with three radio spots produced by New York City Health Dept to promote his opposition to smoking in all public places, including bars and restaurants, which currently operate under more lenient laws (S)

byline.original: By Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken his campaign for smoke-free-workplace legislation to the airwaves, with three radio spots produced by the city's health department to promote his opposition to smoking. Mr. Bloomberg has introduced legislation to ban smoking in all public places, including bars and restaurants, which currently operate under more lenient laws. The department's spokeswoman, Sandra Mullin, said, ''Public education efforts have to undo decades of misinformation about the effects of smoking.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

headline.main: Cellphone: A Convenience, a Hazard or Both?

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column explores questions about whether cellphones are safe and what effect they have on quality of life; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When a new technology takes off, it seems to fly with the speed of light. So it is with cellphones, now owned by well over half the population and soon to be found in more than 90 percent of American households. The latest trend is to replace one's land line with a cellphone, but that action seems a bit premature, given the erratic nature of many cellphone connections.
